dirty.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: covered in or marked by an unwanted substance
dirty.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a stack of dirty dishes in the sink
How did you get so dirty?
She circled the bedroom, picking up dirty clothes.
dirty.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: relating to sex, in a way that is considered immoral or unpleasant
dirty.translation[0].definitions[1].note: dirty weekend British English (=a weekend when a man and woman who are not married to each other go away to have sex)
dirty.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She looked at me as if I had said a dirty word.
dirty.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to emphasize that you think someone or something is bad, dishonest, or immoral
dirty.translation[0].definitions[2].note: do the dirty on somebody British English (=treat someone in a way that is unfair or dishonest)
dirty.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: you and your dirty little deals
dirty.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a dirty sports event is one in which people competing in the event have illegally used drugs to improve their performance
dirty.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Many people think that the race has been a dirty event for years.
dirty.translation[0].note_box[0].section: not clean
His clothes were untidy and he had dirty hands.
filthy
very dirty
Each year filthy water causes millions of cases of illness.
muddy
covered with mud
It had been raining hard and the path was muddy.
dusty
covered with dust
the dusty shelves in the attic
greasy
covered with oil or grease
Greasy food is bad for your health.
grubby
fairly dirty and needing to be cleaned or washed
He was wearing a grubby white T-shirt.
mucky fingers
grimy
covered with thick dirt or dirt that has been there a long time
I couldn’t see much out of the grimy windows of the train.
dingy
looking dark, dirty, and unpleasant. Used about rooms, houses, and buildings
We worked in a dingy little office behind the station.
polluted
used about land, water, or air that has been made dirty
85% of city dwellers breathe heavily polluted air.
contaminated
made dirty by a dangerous substance or bacteria
The virus is mainly spread through contaminated food.
squalid
extremely dirty and unpleasant. Used about the place or conditions in which someone lives
People are living in squalid conditions, with little water and no sanitation.
unhygienic
used about dirty conditions that are likely to cause disease, especially conditions in kitchens, restaurants, and hospitals
The food was prepared under unhygienic conditions.
unsanitary
used about dirty conditions that are likely to cause disease, especially because there is not a good system for getting rid of waste
People’s health is being threatened by overcrowded and insanitary homes.
They work for long hours in unsanitary conditions.
soiled
made dirty, especially by waste from your body
Soiled nappies should be changed as quickly as possible.
dirty.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to make someone feel or seem bad, dishonest, or immoral
dirty.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The army’s actions dirtied its reputation.
dirty.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: revelations about dirty dealing in the Treasury bond market
He accused the government of dirty tricks against the Republicans.
